conclusion: Analyze the motion of the negatively charged particle as it moves through the electric and magnetic fields.
The particle is injected along the central line SO of the metal plates and moves in a straight line due to the electric field.
The electric field exerts a force \( F_e = qE \) on the particle, where \( E \) is the electric field strength.
The particle accelerates under this force, but since it moves in a straight line, the velocity component perpendicular to the plates remains unchanged.
Upon entering the magnetic field, the particle experiences a magnetic force \( F_m = qvB \), where \( v \) is the velocity of the particle and \( B \) is the magnetic induction strength.
This force acts perpendicular to the velocity of the particle, causing it to move in a circular path.
The radius \( r \) of the circular path is given by \( r = \frac{mv}{qB} \).
The particle moves in a circular path with radius \( r \) and just fails to exit the magnetic field from side cd.
The maximum distance it can travel horizontally within the magnetic field is \( 2L \), which is the side length of the square abcd.
For the particle to just fail to exit, the diameter of the circular path must be equal to the side length of the square, i.e., \( 2r = 2L \).
From the condition \( 2r = 2L \), we have \( r = L \).
Substituting the expression for \( r \), we get \( \frac{mv}{qB} = L \).
Rearrange the equation to solve for \( v \): \( v = \frac{qBL}{m} \).
The magnitude of the velocity of the particle when it is shot into point S is \( v = \frac{qBL}{m} \).
